The refund application filed on 30-10-1985 immediately after the RT-12 assessment on 29-10-1985 falls within the 6-month limitation period. Lower authorities erred in treating PLA debits as final payments, warranting reversal by the Supreme Court on statutory interpretation grounds.

cases.graph_reasoning: The ex parte divorce decree was valid and in force on the date of the second marriage (25.05.1993), meaning the first marriage was not subsisting at that time, precluding any offence under Section 494 IPC. Setting aside the decree in 1994 does not retrospectively validate the bigamy charge, as criminal liability cannot be imposed based on subsequent events. Arguments regarding adultery post-1994 pertain to a different offence (Section 497 IPC) and do not sustain the Section 494 proceedings, warranting quashing and acceptance of the appeal.
cases.struct_reasoning: The second marriage was contracted on 25.5.1993 when the ex parte divorce decree was valid and operative, rendering the first marriage non-subsisting at that time. The subsequent setting aside of the decree on 31.3.1994 does not retrospectively validate a bigamy offence under Section 494 IPC, as criminal liability is assessed based on facts and legal status existing on the date of the second marriage. The respondent's argument shifts to adultery post-31.3.1994, which pertains to Section 497 IPC (not charged) and does not support a Section 494 prosecution for the prior act of marriage.

cases.graph_reasoning: The allotment explicitly granted only a life estate to Smt. Bachan Kaur for her lifetime maintenance, prohibiting her from conveying absolute title beyond her interest. Section 41 of the TPA protects bona fide transferees from ostensible owners only during the limited owner's lifetime and does not extend to reversioners like the State after her death. Respondents' reliance on precedents is outweighed by the no-better-title principle and the explicit terms of the grant, favoring the State's claim.
cases.struct_reasoning: The widow held only a life estate, which cannot be alienated beyond her lifetime, limiting her transfer to a possessory interest at best. Section 41 of the TPA requires the real owner's consent to the ostensible owner's apparent absolute title, which the State did not provide, as the allotment order explicitly limited it to her lifetime. Precedents like Mt. Phool Kuer emphasize strict conditions for Section 41 protection, likely leading the Supreme Court to overturn the High Court's ruling in favor of the State.

cases.graph_reasoning: Prosecution relies heavily on confessional statements of co-accused, which under Evidence Act Section 30 can only lend assurance to other evidence and not serve as its foundation, especially with retractions and post-arrest nature excluding Section 10. Star prosecution witnesses (PWs 40,67,68) have doubtful antecedents, evidentiary fallacies, delays without explanation, and lack of independent corroboration like non-examined Nausad and Osman, rendering the case suspect. Claims of accidental explosion and private defence further undermine intent for conspiracy or terrorist acts under TADA/IPC, tilting merits towards accepting the appeal and setting aside convictions.
cases.struct_reasoning: The prosecution's evidence, including star witnesses directly observing bomb preparation and conspiracy discussions linked to communal riots, coupled with recovered explosives and corroborated confessions under Section 164 CrPC, strongly establishes criminal conspiracy under Section 120B IPC and terrorist acts under TADA Sections 3(2)(i) and 3(3). Appellants' claims of unreliable witnesses (due to antecedents and delay), retracted confessions, and self-defense are undermined by the scale of explosives in a populated area causing demolition and deaths, negating accident or private defense theories. Supreme Court precedents like Mohd. Khalid affirm TADA applicability, and the Designated Court's conviction on key charges reflects cogent proof, likely leading to appeal dismissal.

cases.graph_reasoning: The appointment was explicitly temporary under Rule 27 of the Rajasthan Municipal Service Rules, 1963, limited to one year without PSC concurrence and terminable upon PSC candidate availability, which occurred after the appellant twice declined PSC selections. Long service does not confer regularization rights for ad-hoc/temporary posts without proper PSC selection, and no presumption of PSC concurrence arises from extensions, as legitimate expectation requires representation or practice absent here. Supreme Court precedents consistently deny permanency or regularization in such cases, favoring strict adherence to service rules over equity.
cases.struct_reasoning: The appellant's appointment was explicitly temporary under Rule 27 of the Rajasthan Municipal Service Rules, 1963, conditioned to last until an RPSC-selected candidate was available, which occurred, justifying termination despite extensions. Supreme Court precedents like State of Haryana v. Piara Singh (1992) emphasize that long service alone does not confer regularization rights for ad hoc/temporary posts without a substantive vacancy or procedural compliance. Principles of legitimate expectation do not override the clear conditional terms, and the appellant's refusal to join RPSC selections twice further weakens her claim.

cases.graph_reasoning: The prosecution must strictly prove that an offence under Section 306 IPC was committed, the appellants' knowledge or reason to believe it, and intent to screen the offender by causing evidence disappearance under Section 201 IPC, which is not established merely by family ties, presence, or hasty cremation claimed due to decomposition after police intimation. No autopsy or proof of unnatural death weakens the chain, and cited precedents like Palvinder Kaur and others stress that suspicion alone is insufficient for conviction. The Supreme Court is likely to accept the appeal and set aside the conviction on legal merits.
cases.struct_reasoning: The Sessions Court and High Court concurrently found that the appellants hastily cremated the deceased's body without proper police inquest or formalities, despite it being an unnatural death, indicating knowledge of an offence (abetment to suicide under Section 306 IPC by Baldev Singh) and intent to cause disappearance of evidence under Section 201 IPC. The appellants' claim of informing the police and completing formalities was disbelieved based on prosecution evidence, including the father's testimony. Supreme Court generally upholds such concurrent findings on facts unless perverse, and cited precedents support conviction for causing disappearance in similar circumstances.

cases.graph_reasoning: The Union's arguments are stronger, supported by consistent central legislation (e.g., Oil Fields Act, 1948; Petroleum Rules, 1959) defining natural gas as a petroleum product under Entry 53 List I, indicating exclusive Union competence. Doctrines of pith and substance and harmonious construction exclude natural gas from Entry 25 List II, which pertains to manufactured or synthetic gas, distinguishing precedents like Calcutta Gas Company. The writ petition challenging Union's legislative competence on gas will thus be dismissed.
cases.struct_reasoning: Natural gas is encompassed within Entry 53 of List I as 'petroleum and petroleum products,' supported by explicit inclusions in Union statutes like the Oilfields (Regulation and Development) Act, 1948, and extensive central legislation occupying the field. Entry 25 of List II applies to manufactured or town gas (as in Calcutta Gas Co.), not natural gas from oilfields, which requires uniform national regulation due to interstate pipelines and resource development. Thus, States lack competence, rendering the Gujarat Act ultra vires, upholding the Union's exclusive legislative domain.

cases.graph_reasoning: Under Section 30 of the Arbitration Act, 1940, courts have very limited jurisdiction to set aside awards, confined to specific grounds like misconduct, without reappraising evidence or interfering with the arbitrator's discretion on adjournments. The arbitrators' refusal to grant further opportunity after a four-year delay since 1995, following the respondent's unexplained absence, does not amount to misconduct, and the High Court exceeded its scope by substituting its view. Precedents emphasize finality of awards and non-interference with discretionary orders absent perversity, favoring restoration of the award.
cases.struct_reasoning: The Supreme Court is likely to accept the appeal as the High Court's interference exceeds the limited grounds under Section 30 of the Arbitration Act, 1940, which requires serious misconduct, not mere refusal of adjournment for respondent's absence despite waiting till late. Precedents like Arosan Enterprises and State of U.P. v. Allied Constructions emphasize minimal judicial scrutiny of arbitral awards to ensure finality, especially after prolonged proceedings since 1995. Respondent's explanation for absence appears frivolous, and evidence was already concluded in one case, making the High Court's remission unjustified.

cases.graph_reasoning: The core issue revolves around whether prior declaratory decrees in favor of the reversioner (appellant) operate as res judicata against the enlargement of Uttamdassi's limited maintenance estate into an absolute estate under Section 14(1) of the Hindu Succession Act, 1956. Interpretation of Section 14 is a pure question of law that overrides earlier decrees, as res judicata does not apply to decisions contrary to prevailing statutory interpretation or subsequent authoritative rulings like V. Tulasamma. The High Court's finding that the declaratory decrees do not entitle the appellant to possession aligns with these principles, making the appeal likely to be rejected.
cases.struct_reasoning: The appellant obtained two final declaratory decrees prior to the V. Tulasamma judgment (1977), declaring that Uttamdassi's alienations did not affect her reversionary rights, which bind the parties under Section 11 CPC res judicata principles. Even if Tulasamma interpreted Section 14(1) HSA to confer absolute ownership retrospectively, final judgments cannot be invalidated by subsequent rulings, as supported by precedents like Teg Singh and ECIL emphasizing protection of vested rights from prospective overruling. Lower courts erred in disregarding these decrees for the possession suit, entitling the appellant to the fruits of her declarations as nearest reversioner post-Uttamdassi's death.

cases.graph_reasoning: The central legal doctrines emphasize that regularization is only possible against sanctioned posts, and courts cannot direct the creation of posts, as this violates separation of powers and encroaches on executive functions. The facts confirm no sanctioned tractor driver post existed, plaintiffs were appointed and regularized as Mali, and the trial court correctly found against regularization. Precedents like Indian Drugs and Ram Jawaya reinforce judicial restraint, making it highly likely the Supreme Court will accept the appeal and set aside the High Court's directive.
cases.struct_reasoning: The Supreme Court consistently holds that courts cannot direct the creation of new posts or regularization against non-sanctioned vacancies, as this encroaches on executive functions involving policy and finances, per separation of powers (e.g., Indian Drugs & Pharmaceuticals Ltd. v. Workmen). Here, no tractor driver post existed, and plaintiffs were regularized as Mali, making lower courts' directives erroneous. Petitioner's arguments align with precedents limiting judicial interference in staffing decisions.

cases.graph_reasoning: The case involves a private financial dispute over a vehicle finance transaction that has been settled between the parties, with no broader public interest implicated. Supreme Court precedents like B.S. Joshi v. State of Haryana establish that inherent powers under Section 482 CrPC or Article 226 can quash proceedings for non-compoundable offences like Sections 420/468/471 IPC in such cases to prevent abuse of process, overriding Section 320(9) via harmonious construction. The High Court's refusal to quash is likely to be set aside on appeal, favoring the petitioners' position.
cases.struct_reasoning: The Supreme Court is likely to accept the appeal based on the precedent in B.S. Joshi v. State of Haryana, which allows quashing of FIRs for non-compoundable offences under Section 482 CrPC when parties settle amicably and continuation serves no public interest. Here, the dispute is a private financial fraud resolved by settlement with the complainant's affidavit withdrawing allegations, aligning with ends of justice principles from Madhu Limaye and Pepsi Foods. Respondents' arguments for reconsideration are undermined by supportive precedents like Nikhil Merchant, favoring inherent powers over rigid non-compoundability.

cases.graph_reasoning: The affidavit and verification in the election petition did not comply with Form 25 requirements, particularly by failing to disclose the source of information for paragraphs based on information rather than personal knowledge, which is a material defect going to the root of the corrupt practice allegations under Section 83(1)(c) RP Act. Despite having sufficient opportunity to cure the defects, the petitioner took no steps, justifying the High Court's dismissal under analogous application of Order VII Rule 11 CPC. Supreme Court precedents mandate strict compliance for affidavits in election petitions alleging corrupt practices, treating such non-compliance as fatal rather than a minor curable irregularity.
cases.struct_reasoning: Defects in the affidavit (improper affirmation and certification wording) and verification (lacking sources of information for non-personal knowledge paras, vague allegations) are fatal under Sections 83 and 85 of the RP Act 1951 and Rule 94A, as election petitions require strict compliance to prevent frivolous claims. Precedents like Murarka Radhey Shyam and H.D. Revanna emphasize mandatory affidavit in prescribed Form 25 without substantial defects. Petitioner had ample time (from 22.6.2006 to 30.8.2006 first hearing) to cure but did not, justifying High Court's dismissal without further opportunity.

cases.graph_reasoning: Section 25 of the Pondicherry Act grants the High Court wide revisional powers, broader than Section 115 CPC, allowing interference with findings of fact for correctness, legality, or propriety, as supported by precedents like Punnoose cases interpreting similar provisions. The facts confirm the building's dilapidated state (60 years old with cracks) and landlord's permissions for demolition, justifying eviction under the relevant grounds. The tenant's argument against High Court reversal lacks merit given the statute's explicit scope, making dismissal of the appeal likely.
cases.struct_reasoning: The core issue is whether the High Court could interfere with the factual findings of the Appellate Authority in its revisional jurisdiction under Section 25 of the Pondicherry Buildings Lease and Rent Control Act, 1969. Indian Supreme Court precedents, such as the cited M. Punnoose case, consistently hold that revisional powers are limited to jurisdictional errors or perversity and do not permit re-appreciation of evidence like a second appeal. Thus, the tenant-appellant's argument is meritorious, and the Supreme Court is likely to set aside the High Court's order restoring the trial court's decree.

cases.graph_reasoning: The Family Court and High Court's findings that the appellant was not married to Lakshmi violate natural justice (audi alteram partem), as Lakshmi was not made a party or given notice, rendering those findings null and void. Without validly disproving the subsisting first marriage (supported by appellant's evidence like ration card, photos, and son's documents), the respondent's claimed second marriage is void, disqualifying her from maintenance under Section 125 CrPC. The significant delay in the respondent's petition further weakens her claim, making the appeal likely to be accepted by setting aside the lower court orders.
cases.struct_reasoning: The lower courts violated principles of natural justice by adjudicating the validity of the appellant's alleged marriage to Lakshmi without issuing notice to or hearing her as a necessary party, rendering their findings unsustainable. The appellant produced substantial documentary evidence (ration card, voter ID, son's transfer certificate, hospital records, wedding photos) supporting his 1980 marriage to Lakshmi, which would render any subsequent 1986 marriage to the respondent void under Hindu law prohibiting bigamy. The 12-year delay in the respondent's Section 125 Cr.P.C. petition further weakens her claim, making it likely the Supreme Court will set aside the lower courts' decisions.

cases.graph_reasoning: The Supreme Court is likely to invoke the doctrine of prospective overruling under Article 142, as it has done in similar Article 371-D cases like V. Jagannadha Rao and Govt. of A.P. v. B. Satyanarayana Rao, to protect long-held promotions and avoid harsh reversion, given the law's prior uncertainty. Lower courts like the Tribunal and High Court cannot invoke this doctrine, making the High Court's setting aside of prospective application subject to Supreme Court modification. The Presidential Order prevails, invalidating the rules, but relief will be moulded prospectively for complete justice.
cases.struct_reasoning: The Supreme Court has the exclusive authority to invoke the doctrine of prospective overruling, as affirmed in precedents like Golak Nath, and can exercise it here under Article 142 to prevent hardship from reverting employees who held promotions for nearly a decade under rules valid at the time amid legal flux until Jagannadha Rao (2001). The appellants' non-impleadment in prior proceedings strengthens their case for protection, and SC has frequently applied prospective relief in service disputes to uphold equity. The High Court's reversal of the Tribunal's prospective application is likely to be set aside in favor of saving past promotions.

cases.graph_reasoning: The 10% deposit clause is manifestly arbitrary under Article 14, acting as a disproportionate clog on arbitration access with no rational nexus to curbing frivolous claims, leading to unjust forfeiture even on partial success, as per Central Inland Water Transport and doctrine of proportionality. State instrumentalities must adhere to fairness in contracts, and judicial review applies to ex facie arbitrary tender terms despite limited scrutiny under Tata Cellular. Respondents' equality plea fails as it practically burdens weaker claimants, aligning with striking down adhesion contracts.
cases.struct_reasoning: The clause applies equally to both parties, ensuring no discrimination under Article 14, and courts refrain from interfering in commercial tender terms unless clearly arbitrary, as per Tata Cellular and Directorate of Education. The Brojo Nath Ganguly principle on unconscionable clauses is inapplicable to arm's-length commercial contracts between a private company and state instrumentality. The 10% deposit serves as a reasonable deterrent to frivolous claims without clogging arbitration, aligning with precedents upholding such security mechanisms.
